questions.text: What is the spot diagnosis for the given image?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Pearly white mass behind Intact Tympanic membrane is indicative of Congenital cholesteatoma(Levenson's Criteria)

Congenital cholesteatoma

  • It arises from the embryonic epidermal cell resting in the middle ear cleft or temporal bone. Congenital cholesteatoma occurs at three important sites: the middle ear, the petrous apex and the cerebellopontine angle, and produces symptomatology depending on its location.
  • A middle ear congenital cholesteatoma presents as a white mass behind an intact tympanic membrane and causes conductive hearing loss. It may sometimes be discovered on routine examination of children or at the time of myringotomy.
  • It may also spontaneously rupture through the tympanic membrane and present with a discharging ear indistinguishable from a case of chronic suppurative otitis media.

Explanation of other options:

Primary acquired Cholesteatoma(Option A): It is called primary as there is no history of previous otitis media or a pre-existing perforation. Theories of its generation are:

  • Invagination of pars flaccida: Persistent negative pressure in the attic causes a retraction pocket, which accumulates keratin debris. When infected, the keratin mass expands towards the middle ear. Thus, the attic perforation is the proximal end of an expanding invaginated sac. (Wittmack's theory).
  • Basal cell hyperplasia.
  • Squamous metaplasia.

Primary acquired cholesteatoma arising from the retraction pocket:

Secondary acquired cholesteatoma(Option B): In these cases, there is already a pre-existing perforation in the pars tensa. This is often associated with posterosuperior marginal perforation or sometimes large central perforation. Theories of its generation are:

  • Migration of the Squamous epithelium.
  • Metaplasia

Tertiary acquired cholesteatoma(Option C): Emerges behind a normal-appearing tympanic membrane, often due to implantation during otitis media or minor trauma.

questions.text: Blood-stained foul foul-smelling ear discharge with the otoscopy findings given in the image, what is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Primary Acquired Cholesteatoma (most common type).
  • This type of Cholesteatoma originates from Retraction Pockets, which are most common in the Pars Flaccida.
  • This theory is called Wittmack's Theory.
  • The most common site of cholesteatoma formation in the middle ear cleft is Prussak's space.

Chief complaints :

  • Ear discharge- scanty, foul-smelling (due to bone erosion) and blood-stained (due to granulation formation).
  • Hearing loss is mostly conductive, sometimes mixed (CHL+ SNHL)

Treatment :

  • Surgery is called MRM (Modified Radical Mastoidectomy), also known as Tympanomastoid exploration.
  • The main aim of MRM is to make the ear safe.
  • After making adequate clearance of cholesteatoma, we remove the posterior wall of the EAC to open the mastoid cavity into the EAC.
  • Hence, MRM is a classical example of canal wall down surgery (CWD).
  • Canal wall means the posterior wall of EAC, and down means removed.

Explanation of the other options:

Secondary acquired cholesteatoma(Option B): In these cases, there is already a pre-existing perforation in the pars tensa. This is often associated with posterosuperior marginal perforation or sometimes large central perforation. Theories of its generation are:

  • Migration of the Squamous epithelium.
  • Metaplasia

Tertiary acquired cholesteatoma(Option C): Emerges behind a normal-appearing tympanic membrane, often due to implantation during otitis media or minor trauma.

Congenital cholesteatoma(Option D):

  • It arises from the embryonic epidermal cell resting in the middle ear cleft or temporal bone. Congenital cholesteatoma occurs at three important sites: the middle ear, the petrous apex and the cerebellopontine angle, and produces symptomatology depending on its location.
  • A middle ear congenital cholesteatoma presents as a white mass behind an intact tympanic membrane and causes conductive hearing loss. It may sometimes be discovered on routine examination of children or at the time of myringotomy.
  • It may also spontaneously rupture through the tympanic membrane and present with a discharging ear indistinguishable from a case of chronic suppurative otitis media.

choices.text: Collagenase and acid phosphatase release by osteoclasts
Proteolytic enzymes liberated by mononuclear cells

questions.text: Which of the following is not the biochemical mechanism of bone erosion caused by cholesteatoma in atticoantral CSOM?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pressure is never the biochemical mechanism of bone erosion caused by congenital cholesteatoma.

Mechanism of bone erosion in Cholesteatoma:

Inflammatory Osteitis( Option D ruled out):

  • Chronic inflammation releases Cytokines (e.g., TNF-α, IL-1, IL-6) and Prostaglandins (especially PGE2).
  • These stimulate osteoclast activity, accelerating bone resorption.

Enzymatic theory-Bone destroying Enzyme(Option B and C ruled out):

  • Cholesteatoma epithelium and associated inflammatory cells release proteolytic enzymes, such as Collagenases, Matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs) and Hydrolases.
  • These enzymes degrade bone matrix and connective tissue.

questions.text: What is the most common site of residual cholesteatoma after mastoid exploration in a case of unsafe CSOM?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Sinus tympani:

  • Sinus tympani is a deep recess on the medial wall of the middle ear. It is a hidden area and the most common site of residual cholesteatoma after mastoid surgery.
  • A study where otoendoscopy was used post-microscopically on 150 patients found that 88.9% of hidden residual cholesteatoma was located in the sinus tympani, making it the leading site ahead of the facial recess, anterior epitympanum, and hypotympanum.
  • The sinus tympani is a notorious "blind spot" during microscopic surgery, which explains why it's the most common location for disease leftover.

Boundaries of facial Recess:

  • Superior - Ponticulus
  • Inferior - Subiculum
  • Lateral - Limited by the vertical segment of the facial nerve.

questions.text: A patient with right unsafe CSOM has presented with a history of diplopia and pain behind the right eye. What is the further ideal investigation in this clinical scenario?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Retro-orbital pain and diplopia are suggestive of petrositis. Along with otorrhoea, it forms the triad of Gradenigo syndrome.
  • Diagnosis of petrous apicitis requires HRCT temporal bone, which shows an abscess at the Petrous apex.
  • This allows detailed imaging of the petrous bone structure and any bony erosion or collection. If further evaluation of soft tissue and intracranial extension is needed, MRI may follow, but CT is the primary tool to detect bony involvement.
  • Petrositis arises from infection spreading to the petrous apex of the temporal bone, leading to involvement of the abducens (VI) nerve-leading to lateral rectus palsy and diplopia-along with deep-seated orbital pain via trigeminal (V) nerve involvement.

Explanation of other options:

Audiometry(Option A): Useful for hearing assessment, but not the priority when intracranial or orbital complications are suspected.

Aural swab for C&S(Option C): Helps guide antibiotic therapy, but does not evaluate the extent of disease or complications.

Vestibular evoked myogenic potentials (VEMP)(Option D): Used for vestibular pathway evaluation, not helpful in this condition.

Treatment - Cortical, modified radical or radical mastoidectomy + IV antibiotics.

choices.text: Atticoantral CSOM with Lateral sinus thrombosis

questions.text: Mohan, a 22-year-old, gives a history of right-sided ear discharge, foul-smelling and occasionally blood-stained, for the last 6 years. He also complains of hearing loss for the last 2 years. For the last 3 days, the patient has developed fever with chills, headache and oedema over the mastoid region. The most probable diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Scanty, foul-smelling ear discharge is seen in attic-antral CSOM.
  • The patient recently developed fever with chills, headache and oedema over the mastoid(Griesinger sign). All these point to a diagnosis of Sigmoid sinus thrombosis(Lateral sinus thrombosis).
  • The treatment is Modified radical mastoidectomy with opening of the sinus wall and removal of thrombus + i/v antibiotics.

Complications of CSOM:

Intratemporal(within the temporal bone):

  • Mastoiditis
  • Petrositis
  • Facial paralysis
  • Labyrinthitis

Intracranial:

  • Extradural abscess
  • Subdural abscess
  • Meningitis
  • Brain abscess
  • Lateral sinus thrombophlebitis
  • Otitic hydrocephalus.

Explanation of other options:

Tubotympanic CSOM(Option A): Rarely causes serious complications like meningitis

Brain abscess(Option B): It is possible with unsafe CSOM, but presentation usually includes focal neurological deficits or progressive mental status changes, not just mastoid oedema

Subdural empyema(Option D): Typically shows signs of increased intracranial pressure, mental status change, and rapid worsening, which isn't described in her case.

questions.text: A 20-year-old Male presents with unilateral Ear discharge, pallor, fever and positive Crowe Beck Test. The clinical diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Crowe Beck sign is seen in Sigmoid sinus thrombosis(Lateral sinus thrombosis).
  • It is the engorgement of retinal veins due to pressure on the jugular vein of the healthy side, seen on fundoscopy. This is absent on the affected side. This is due to the blockage of venous drainage of the brain.
  • Additional features-fever, pallor, and ear discharge-are consistent with chronic ear infection (CSOM) leading to sigmoid (lateral) sinus thrombosis.

Lateral sinus thrombosis:

  • It is an inflammation of the inner wall of the lateral venous sinus with formation of an intrasinus thrombus.
  • It occurs as a complication of acute coalescent mastoiditis, masked mastoiditis or chronic suppuration of the middle ear and cholesteatoma.

Clinical features:

  • Hectic- Picket- Fence type of fever with rigours.Papilledema.
  • Griesinger sign.
  • Progressive anaemia and emaciation.
  • Tobey-Eyer test positive.
  • Crowe Beck test positive
  • Tenderness along the jugular vein.

Explanation of other options:

Cavernous Sinus Thrombosis(Option A): More commonly associated with facial infections, periorbital swelling, proptosis, and cranial nerve III, IV, V1, and VI palsies. Not typical of ear disease.

Sagittal Sinus Thrombosis(Option C): Rare in otogenic infections, and presents more with headache, seizures, and altered sensorium.

Brain Abscess(Option D): May occur as a complication of CSOM but usually presents with focal neurological deficits, raised intracranial pressure, headache, and altered consciousness, not Crowe-Beck positivity.

questions.text: The Aim of mastoid surgery in unsafe CSOM, which should receive priority, is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In unsafe CSOM (e.g., with cholesteatoma and bone erosion), the primary, non-negotiable goal of mastoid surgery is to render the ear safe.
  • The hallmark of this disease is the presence of Cholesteatoma.

Primary Acquired Cholesteatoma (most common type):

  • This type of Cholesteatoma originates from Retraction Pockets. They are most common in the Pars Flaccida.
  • This theory is called Wittgat's theory.

Chief complaints :

  • Ear discharge- scanty, foul-smelling (due to bone erosion) and blood-stained (due to granulation formation).
  • Hearing loss is mostly conductive, sometimes mixed (CHL+ SNHL)

Treatment :

  • Surgery is called MRM (Modified Radical Mastoidectomy), also known as the TympanoMastoid exploration.
  • The main aim of MRM is to make the ear safe.
  • After making adequate clearance of cholesteatoma, we remove the posterior wall of the EAC to open the mastoid cavity into the EAC.
  • Hence, MRM is a classical example of canal wall down surgery (CWD).
  • Canal wall means the posterior wall of EAC, and down means removed.

The below given image shows the Primary Acquired Cholesteatoma.

choices.text: Modified radical Mastoidectomy and fistula repair

questions.text: In unsafe CSOM with vertigo and positive fistula sign, the treatment of choice is:
A patient having foul-smelling ear discharge and cholesteatoma in the middle ear presents with facial nerve palsy; the treatment of choice is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The main treatment of Cholesteatoma is surgery, which is MRM ( Modified Radical Mastectomy).

Treatment :

  • It is also known as the TympanoMastoid exploration.
  • The main aim of MRM is to make the ear safe.
  • After making adequate clearance of cholesteatoma, we remove the posterior wall of the EAC to open the mastoid cavity into the EAC.
  • Hence, MRM is a classical example of canal wall down surgery (CWD).
  • Canal wall means the posterior wall of EAC, and down means removed.
  • The most common site of residual cholesteatoma after mastoid surgery is the Sinus Tympani.

Meatoplasty:

  • This surgical step is aimed at widening the EAC. It is done by removing the part of the Conchal cartilage.

Uses:

  • Adequate ventilation of mastoid cavities.
  • Proper inspection & cleaning of mastoid cavities.

Explanation of other options:

Radical mastoidectomy(Option A): More destructive, used in cases where hearing cannot be preserved.

Oral steroids(Option C): May be adjunctive but not curative or sufficient.

Ear drops(Option D): Symptomatic relief, not a definitive treatment.

choices.text: Granulations in the middle ear cleft

questions.text: False about atticoantral chronic suppurative otitis media is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Attic CSOM always presents with marginal or attic perforation.

choices.text: Topical antibiotics and decongestants for 4 weeks
IV antibiotics and follow-up after a month

questions.text: A child presented with an ear infection with foul-smelling discharge. On further exploration, a small perforation is found in the pars flaccida of the tympanic membrane. What would be the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Foul-smelling discharge with perforation of the pars flaccida of the tympanic membrane is suggestive of atticoantral CSOM.
  • It is always managed surgically(Option A and B ruled out). So tympanomastoid exploration(MRM) is the correct answer.
  • Tympanoplasty is done after the surgical removal of the infection, that is, cholesteatoma(Option C ruled out).

Atticoantral CSOM:

  • It involves the posterosuperior part of the middle ear cleft (attic, antrum, posterior tympanum and mastoid) and is associated with cholesteatoma, which, because of its bone-eroding properties, causes a risk of serious complications. For this reason, the disease is also called unsafe or dangerous.
  • The aetiology of atticoantral disease is the same as that of cholesteatoma. It is seen in sclerotic mastoid, and whether the latter is the cause or effect of the disease is not yet clear.

Clinical features:

  • Foul-smelling discharge.
  • Hearing loss.
  • Bleeding
  • Marginal perforation.
  • Retraction pocket.
  • Cholesteatoma

questions.text:
Which of the following is not true about tubercular otitis media?
a. Blood-stained ear discharge
b. Pale granulations in the middle ear & mastoid
c. Facial paralysis
d. Multiple perforations in the tympanic membrane
e. Painful due to underlying bone destruction
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Tubercular otitis media:

Clinical features:

  • Painless otorrhoea - The ear discharge is foul-smelling due to underlying bone destruction. (Statement e is incorrect)
  • Pale granulations in the middle ear and mastoid. It does not have blood-stained discharge. (Statement a is incorrect)
  • Multiple perforations in the pars tensa of the tympanic membrane.
  • Facial palsy → most common complication.

Aetiology:

  • In most cases, infection is secondary to pulmonary tuberculosis; infection reaches the middle ear through the eustachian tube.
  • Sometimes, it is blood-borne from m tubercular focus in the lungs, tonsils, cervical or mesenteric lymph nodes.
  • Disease is mostly seen in children a young adults.

Treatment:

  • Systemic Anti-Tubercular Drugs.
  • Local treatment in the form oan f an aural toilet.
  • Mastoid surgery.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female patient has presented with the complaint of long-standing left ear discharge, foul-smelling, blood stained. She had left-sided facial palsy. She also gives a history of earache, which is worse at night. On otoscopy, friable granulations are seen in the middle ear. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient is middle-aged with long-standing blood-tinged ear discharge and ear ache worse at night. She also has granulations in the middle ear. All these point to a diagnosis of Malignancy of the middle ear.

Clinical features of Middle Ear Malignancy:

  • Patients often present with clinical pictures simulating chronic suppurative otitis media. However, the following features in the age group of 40-60 years may arouse suspicion of malignancy:
  • Chronic foul-smelling discharge, especially blood-stained.Which is usually severe and comes at night.
  • Facial palsy.
  • Friable, haemorrhagic granulations opolypsyp.
  • Appearance of or increase in hearing loss or vertigo.

Treatment:

  • A combination of surgery and radiotherapy gives better results.
  • Surgery consists of radical mastoidectomy, subtotal or total petrosectomy depending on the extent of the tumour.

Explanation of other options:

Malignant Otitis Externa(Option A):

  • The key is that granulations are in the middle ear, not the external auditory canal.
  • That strongly points to a middle-ear origin (like cholesteatoma or osteomyelitis), rather than MOE, which characteristically shows granulations in the bony-cartilaginous junction of the external canal.

Glomus Jugulare(Option C ): Typically presents with pulsatile tinnitus, conductive hearing loss, and a red, pulsating mass behind an intact tympanic membrane ("rising sun" sign).

Keratosis Obturans(Option D):

  • Presents most commonly with severe ear pain and hearing loss, especially in younger or bilateral cases.
  • Rarely causes otorrhea, and facial nerve involvement is extremely uncommon, limited to advanced cases where bone erosion extends to the facial canal.

choices.text: Pale granulations in the middle ear

questions.text: Malignant otitis externa is characterised by all of the following except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Necrotising otitis externa, also called malignant otitis externa, is caused by a Pseudomonas infection in an elderly patient with diabetes.
  • Symptoms include severe otalgia, and facial nerve palsy can occur. The granulations are seen in the external auditory canal and not in the middle ear.

Clinical features:

  • Its early manifestations resemble diffuse otitis externa, but there is excruciating pain with the appearance of granulations in the ear canal. Option A ruled out.
  • Facial paralysis is common. Infection may spread to the skull base and jugular for, amen causing multiple cranial nerve palsies. Option B ruled out.
  • Anteriorly, infection spreads to the temporomandibular fossa, posteriorly to the mastoid and medially into the middle ear and petrous bone.

Treatment:

  • Control of Diabetes.
  • Ear toilet.
  • Antibiotics against the causative agent, Pseudomonas.

questions.text: Tertiary acquired cholesteatoma occurs in which of the following entities?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • After a blast injury, a cholesteatoma may arise behind a spontaneously healed tympanic membrane.
  • Tertiary acquired cholesteatoma refers to a specific subtype of acquired cholesteatoma defined by its origin behind an intact tympanic membrane, occurring due to implantation of squamous epithelium following a prior middle ear injury or inflammation.

Explanation of other options:

Perforation(Option A): Leads to secondary acquired cholesteatoma, where epithelium migrates through the perforation, not a tertiary type.

Retraction pocket(Option C): Causes primary acquired cholesteatoma, due to negative pressure in the middle ear, not implantation from injury or surgery.

Eustachian tube dysfunction(Option D) is also a mechanism for primary (or invagination-type) cholesteatoma, not tertiary.

questions.text: The most common hidden site for residual cholesteatoma after the mastoid surgery in Atticoantral CSOM is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most common hidden site for residual cholesteatoma after the mastoid surgery in Atticoantral CSOM is Sinus Tympani due to its deep, hidden anatomy and limited visibility during surgery.

Anatomy: It is a blind spot in the Middle Ear:

  • The sinus tympani is a deep recess located behind the facial nerve, the stapes, and the posterior canal, wall-making it inaccessible via a straight microscope view.
  • This "around-the-corner" positioning makes complete disease removal very difficult in conventional CWU procedures.

High Incidence of Residual Disease:

  • Studies report 22-47% of CWU cases have residual cholesteatoma found intraoperatively, and up to 20-25% recurrence, with the sinus tympani most frequently involved.
  • Even after microscopic removal, endoscopic inspection regularly identifies disease in this hidden recess.

Canal Wall-Up Increases Risk:

  • CWU maintains the posterior canal wall, which benefits hearing and aesthetics, but it limits surgical access to areas like the sinus tympani and facial recess.
  • Compared to canal wall-down (CWD), CWU shows higher residual (19-47% vs 5-12%) and recurrence rates (up to 20%).

Endoscopic and Two-Way Approaches Improve Clearance:

  • Endoscopic-assisted CWU dramatically reduces residual rates (e.g., 37% → 6%) by revealing hidden cholesteatoma.
  • Combined "two-way" CWU (via meatus + mastoid/facial recess) specifically targets sinus tympani access-studies show this approach halves residual disease rates compared to one-way CWU
